rows.title: Counting sounds

transcript.eng:
Sit down and close your eyes.
How many sounds can you hear?  
Listen to the sounds inside and outside the room. Count them on your fingers. 
After ten seconds, how many fingers do you have up? What sounds did you hear? 

Try again for another ten seconds.  
Did you hear any new sounds? Did you hear any sounds inside your own body? 
Notice how you feel now.

rows.transcript:
Sit down and close your eyes.
How many sounds can you hear?  
Listen to the sounds inside and outside the room. Count them on your fingers. 
After ten seconds, how many fingers do you have up? What sounds did you hear? 

Try again for another ten seconds.  
Did you hear any new sounds? Did you hear any sounds inside your own body? 
Notice how you feel now.

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: Well done for recognising a positive feeling. I am happy to hear you are feeling well today!

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: Well done for recognising that you are not feeling great. Be kind to yourself today, you deserve it.

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: Well done for recognising a difficult feeling. It is okay not to be okay sometimes. Remember @global.app_name is here to support you.

quiz_1_feedback_4.eng: Well done for recognising that you are stressed. It’s okay to feel stressed sometimes. Remember to ask for help if you need it!

quiz_1_feedback_5.eng: Well done for recognising that you are feeling tired. Try to get enough rest today.

rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: Well done for recognising a positive feeling. I am happy to hear you are feeling well today!
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: Well done for recognising that you are not feeling great. Be kind to yourself today, you deserve it.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_3: Well done for recognising a difficult feeling. It is okay not to be okay sometimes. Remember @global.app_name is here to support you.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_4: Well done for recognising that you are stressed. It’s okay to feel stressed sometimes. Remember to ask for help if you need it!
rows.quiz_1_feedback_5: Well done for recognising that you are feeling tired. Try to get enough rest today.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Today we are learning to talk about feelings with our children. 

Noticing emotions, both our own and our children's, helps us care for ourselves. 

Noticing and talking about feelings with our children helps them learn to express and manage their emotions – even the difficult ones.

media_title.eng: How will it help you and your family?

media_transcript.eng:
Greetings, everyone.

Does your child ever get so upset that you don’t know what to do? 

You can help your child to manage their emotions better by showing them how to talk about their feelings. In order to talk about feelings you need to first notice and then accept all the emotions we have.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Today we are learning to talk about feelings with our children. 

Noticing emotions, both our own and our children's, helps us care for ourselves. 

Noticing and talking about feelings with our children helps them learn to express and manage their emotions – even the difficult ones.
rows.media_title: How will it help you and your family?
rows.media_transcript:
Greetings, everyone.

Does your child ever get so upset that you don’t know what to do? 

You can help your child to manage their emotions better by showing them how to talk about their feelings. In order to talk about feelings you need to first notice and then accept all the emotions we have.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Let’s look at another family to see how talking about feelings helps them in a practical way:

character_1_text.eng: @data.characters.f3_son_4.name, I have 5 minutes to spend one-on-one time with you. What would you like to do?

character_2_text.eng: Let’s play with the ball outside!

rows.text_1_facilitator: Let’s look at another family to see how talking about feelings helps them in a practical way:
rows.character_1_text: @data.characters.f3_son_4.name, I have 5 minutes to spend one-on-one time with you. What would you like to do?
rows.character_2_text: Let’s play with the ball outside!

character_2_text.eng: I see that your hands are tight and you are speaking loudly. It looks like you are upset, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name. It’s not easy, let’s practise a little bit more. I know you can do it.

rows.character_2_text: I see that your hands are tight and you are speaking loudly. It looks like you are upset, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name. It’s not easy, let’s practise a little bit more. I know you can do it.

character_1_text.eng: Five kicks in a row! You seem really proud to have made it to five, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name!

rows.character_1_text: Five kicks in a row! You seem really proud to have made it to five, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name!

character_1_text.eng: Well done! I am very happy to be able to spend this time with you, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name

rows.character_1_text: Well done! I am very happy to be able to spend this time with you, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name

text_1_facilitator.eng: Let’s talk this through together. What happened when @data.characters.f3_uncle.name and @data.characters.f3_son_4.name decided to play soccer?

quiz_1_question.eng: Why does @data.characters.f3_uncle.name name @data.characters.f3_son_4.name’s feelings when he’s feeling angry?

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: Not quite. Naming emotions might not make someone feel better right away. The goal is to help him recognize his feelings so he can handle them better next time.

quiz_1_option_2_text.eng: To help @data.characters.f3_son_4.name learn to recognise his own emotions

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: That’s right. By naming @data.characters.f3_son_4.name’s emotions, @data.characters.f3_uncle.name models an important skill.

quiz_1_option_3_text.eng: To teach @data.characters.f3_son_4.name how to solve problems on his own.

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: Not really. While solving problems is important, the main goal here is to help @data.characters.f3_son_4.name recognize his emotions. Once he knows what he’s feeling, he’ll be better at solving problems next time.

quiz_1_option_4_text.eng: To distract @data.characters.f3_son_4.name from what’s bothering him.

quiz_1_feedback_4.eng: Not quite. The goal isn’t to take his mind off his feelings. By naming his emotions, @data.characters.f3_uncle.name is helping @data.characters.f3_son_4.name understand what he’s feeling, so he can deal with it better next time.

quiz_2_question.eng: What can we learn from how @data.characters.f3_uncle.name talks about @data.characters.f3_son_4.name’s emotions?

quiz_2_feedback_1.eng: Yes, he does! But he also names @data.characters.f3_son_4.name’s difficult emotions. @data.characters.f3_uncle.name shows us that it is important to identify both positive *and* difficult emotions for our children.

quiz_2_option_2_text.eng: He doesn’t want him to feel frustrated so he ignores it.

quiz_2_feedback_2.eng: Not quite. @data.characters.f3_uncle.name accepts whatever emotions @data.characters.f3_son_4.name is feeling. @data.characters.f3_uncle.name shows us how we can talk about positive *and* difficult emotions with our children in a helpful way.

quiz_2_option_3_text.eng: He uses words to describe @data.characters.f3_son_4.name’s emotions

quiz_2_feedback_3.eng: Yes, @data.characters.f3_uncle.name shows us how we can talk about positive *and* difficult emotions with our children in a helpful way.

quiz_2_option_4_text.eng: He hides his own feelings with @data.characters.f3_son_4.name

quiz_2_feedback_4.eng: He doesn’t hide his own emotions, he names them. By talking about his own feeling of happiness, @data.characters.f3_uncle.name models how his nephew can do the same.

quiz_2_feedback_5.eng: Yes, @data.characters.f3_uncle.name shows us that his nephew’s difficult emotions are not something he needs to ignore or be scared of.

quiz_3_question.eng: What would have happened if @data.characters.f3_uncle.name had criticised or ignored @data.characters.f3_son_4.name’s frustration?

quiz_3_feedback_1.eng: Incorrect. Without the ability to deal with his feelings, the frustration @data.characters.f3_son_4.name was feeling would have increased.

quiz_3_option_2_text.eng: The same problem would happen again next time

quiz_3_feedback_2.eng: Correct. Noticing and naming emotions is very important to support our children and help them learn how to deal with their emotions.

quiz_3_option_3_text.eng: @data.characters.f3_son_4.name would have learned how to catch a ball anyway.

quiz_3_feedback_3.eng: Incorrect. Noticing and naming emotions is very important to support our children and help them learn new skills.

rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: Not quite. Naming emotions might not make someone feel better right away. The goal is to help him recognize his feelings so he can handle them better next time.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: That’s right. By naming @data.characters.f3_son_4.name’s emotions, @data.characters.f3_uncle.name models an important skill.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_3: Not really. While solving problems is important, the main goal here is to help @data.characters.f3_son_4.name recognize his emotions. Once he knows what he’s feeling, he’ll be better at solving problems next time.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_4: Not quite. The goal isn’t to take his mind off his feelings. By naming his emotions, @data.characters.f3_uncle.name is helping @data.characters.f3_son_4.name understand what he’s feeling, so he can deal with it better next time.
rows.quiz_1_question: Why does @data.characters.f3_uncle.name name @data.characters.f3_son_4.name’s feelings when he’s feeling angry?
rows.quiz_1_option_2_text: To help @data.characters.f3_son_4.name learn to recognise his own emotions

rows.quiz_3_feedback_3: Incorrect. Noticing and naming emotions is very important to support our children and help them learn new skills.

section_1_text.eng: Feelings are connected to thoughts and physical sensations.

section_1_extra_text.eng:
Notice when your child is feeling good and when they are feeling bad.

Recognise both positive and difficult emotions.

To recognise, pay attention to your thoughts and to your and your child’s words and actions.

section_2_text.eng:
Be open to how you and your child feel. Accept both negative and positive emotions. All feelings are okay.

Acknowledge your child’s feelings – even the difficult ones.

It is okay for you to also feel difficult emotions about the same issues.

section_2_extra_text.eng:
The six basic emotions each have a message:

😊 Happy → Keep doing what makes you feel good.

☹️ Sad → Something important needs attention.

😠 Angry → Stand up for yourself and set limits.

🤢 Disgusted → Move away from something you don’t like.

😯 Surprised → Stop and pay attention.

😨 Afraid → Run away from danger.

As children get older, they also learn about other emotions such as excitement, frustration, pride, loneliness, peace, guilt, or confusion.

section_3_text.eng:
Get down to your child’s level when talking about feelings.

Use physical and verbal support to make your child feel accepted and loved.

section_3_extra_text.eng:
Commenting on your child’s feelings can help him/her learn self-discipline and emotional awareness

Use words to describe your child’s emotions so they can learn to do the same. This may be hard at first, but it is an important step to help manage emotions! 

Describe what you notice in a calm way: “I notice you’re stomping your feet, talking loudly, and your face looks upset. What are you feeling?”

Share your own feelings with your child. For example, “I know I feel the same way when I can’t go out when I want to.”

section_4_text.eng: When you share your own feelings with your child, you help your child recognise his/her own emotions.

section_4_extra_text.eng:
By sharing your own feelings, you also show your child that it's okay to share their feelings. They will learn to recognise emotions in themselves and others too. 

Model the behaviour you want to see in your child.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Let’s put the tips you have learnt in action:

quiz_1_question.eng: @data.characters.f1_mother.name's son is throwing a tantrum at the front door. It's time to put on his shoes and the family is running late. Tying his shoes is a challenge and he wants to do it himself. How can @data.characters.f1_mother.name respond?

quiz_1_option_1_text.eng: Tie his shoes for him and get out the door. We are late!

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: It is never fun to run late, but @data.characters.f1_mother.name will miss the opportunity to help her son learn to deal with his frustration if she doesn't help him first recognise what he’s feeling.

quiz_1_option_2_text.eng: Understand that her son is feeling frustrated. Sit down and help him name his feelings.

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: That's a great idea. She can also commit to practising shoe tying with him later, when he's more calm and praise him for naming his feelings and for the good effort during their practise session!

section_4_extra_text.eng: By sharing your own feelings, you also show your child that it's okay to share their feelings. They will learn to recognise emotions in themselves and others too.

rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: It is never fun to run late, but @data.characters.f1_mother.name will miss the opportunity to help her son learn to deal with his frustration if she doesn't help him first recognise what he’s feeling.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: That's a great idea. She can also commit to practising shoe tying with him later, when he's more calm and praise him for naming his feelings and for the good effort during their practise session!
rows.quiz_1_question: @data.characters.f1_mother.name's son is throwing a tantrum at the front door. It's time to put on his shoes and the family is running late. Tying his shoes is a challenge and he wants to do it himself. How can @data.characters.f1_mother.name respond?
rows.quiz_1_option_1_text: Tie his shoes for him and get out the door. We are late!
rows.quiz_1_option_2_text: Understand that her son is feeling frustrated. Sit down and help him name his feelings.
rows.text_1_facilitator: Let’s put the tips you have learnt in action:
rows.section_4_extra_text: By sharing your own feelings, you also show your child that it's okay to share their feelings. They will learn to recognise emotions in themselves and others too.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Your home activity is to talk with your child about their feelings during one-on-one time today. It can be something simple, like noticing that they find joy when they play!

quiz_1_question.eng: Are you up for trying? Can you help your child notice their feelings during one-on-one time today?

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: That's great! It might be awkward to talk about feelings at first, but it will get better for everyone with practice.

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: That's okay. Learning to share emotions with our children can be challenging. Take a minute after one-on-one time today to think through the emotions you saw your child display. You might also want to think about the things that you felt!

rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: That's great! It might be awkward to talk about feelings at first, but it will get better for everyone with practice.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: That's okay. Learning to share emotions with our children can be challenging. Take a minute after one-on-one time today to think through the emotions you saw your child display. You might also want to think about the things that you felt!
rows.quiz_1_question: Are you up for trying? Can you help your child notice their feelings during one-on-one time today?
rows.text_1_facilitator: Your home activity is to talk with your child about their feelings during one-on-one time today. It can be something simple, like noticing that they find joy when they play!
